title: Bernardo Freire Barboza da Cruz
text: I am Bernardo, an aeronautical engineer with a BSc in Aeronautical Engineering and (soon: hopefully :P) an MSc in Data Science. My passion lies in both coding and engineering. I am from Zurich üá®üá≠ and have over seven years of experience working as an aeronautical engineer and about two years as a data scientist.

title: Home
text: I am Bernardo, an aeronautical engineer with a BSc in Aeronautical Engineering and (soon: hopefully :P) an MSc in Data Science. My passion lies in both coding and engineering. I am from Zurich üá®üá≠ and have over seven years of experience working as an aeronautical engineer and about two years as a data scientist.

title: Home
text:
üë®üèΩ‚Äçüíª Experience
In my role at Bucher Leichtbau AG, I provided advice and support to all departments regarding initial airworthiness certification. My expertise included interpreting certification specifications, verifying documentation for ‚Äúminor‚Äù and ‚Äúmajor changes,‚Äù and communicating with customers, official bodies, and authorities. I also provided consulting services to the development department for design optimization.
I switched to data science back in 2021. At Crealogix AG, I provided advice and support to the department on new data science and machine learning products. I created prospect and upsell models, extracted information from fact-sheets using a customized OCR, and developed user journeys for chatbot dialogue flow. Furthermore, I developed chatbot solutions using IBM Watson and Spacy.
After Crealogix, I joined Prognolite AG, where I developed regression models to predict turnover and menu sales using customer data and external data such as weather or public holidays. We used Multi-Output Regression, Quartoüëç, R, and Python, and customized API calls to fetch the data from the database - really cool stuff ‚ö°.
At the moment, I am finishing my Master‚Äôs thesis üôà, and soon, I will be working for‚Ä¶ (to be continued üòé).

title: Bernardo Cruz
text:
The Comic Data Scientist
Bernardo Freire Barboza da Cruz, a data scientist with a flair for comedy, embarked on a series of uproarious adventures during his time at Crealogix AG. Armed with his analytical skills and a penchant for laughter, Bernardo brought a unique and hilarious perspective to his role.

title: Bernardo Cruz
text:
The Upside-Down Algorithms
As Bernardo delved into developing prospect and upsell models at Crealogix AG, his comedic genius took center stage. With every line of code he wrote, Bernardo managed to infuse unexpected humor. His algorithms had a mind of their own, suggesting the most bizarre and outrageous upselling strategies, leaving his colleagues in stitches.

title: Bernardo Cruz
section: Laughter in the Midst of Innovation
text:
Laughter in the Midst of Innovation
When Bernardo joined Prognolite AG, his comedy skills found a new playground. As he developed regression models to predict turnover and menu sales, he couldn‚Äôt resist injecting humor into his data analyses. His presentations often turned into hilarious stand-up routines, with his colleagues eagerly awaiting his predictions and punchlines.

title: Bernardo Cruz
text:
The Jester of Insights
With each project at Prognolite AG, Bernardo became known as the ‚ÄúJester of Insights.‚Äù His unconventional approach to data science left everyone in stitches, as he brought levity and amusement to even the most serious of meetings. Bernardo‚Äôs ability to find humor in complex datasets and present them with comedic flair made him an unforgettable presence.
Epilogue: The Comic Luminary
Bernardo‚Äôs comedic antics became legendary within the industry. His colleagues and clients sought out his company not only for his exceptional data science skills but also for the laughter he brought into their lives. Bernardo‚Äôs career showcased the incredible power of humor to transform even the most technical and demanding fields into joy-filled experiences.
As he moved forward in his professional journey, Bernardo left a lasting legacy of laughter and mirth. His comedic genius reminded everyone that work could be both productive and entertaining. Bernardo‚Äôs ability to bring joy and laughter to the workplace served as a reminder that a lighthearted approach can unlock creativity, foster strong relationships, and create unforgettable memories.
The world will forever remember Bernardo as the data scientist who sprinkled humor into his algorithms and brought smiles to the faces of all those around him. His comedic escapades inspired others to find the laughter hidden within their own professional lives, making the world a brighter and happier place.

title: Bernardo Cruz
text:
Prognolite AG (10/2022 - 03/2023)
Develop and maintain machine learning models aimed at reducing food waste in the gastronomic sector. Specifically, the job involves developing regression models to predict turnover and menu sales using customer data and external data such as weather or public holidays.

Maintenance and further development of the restaurant sales forecasting process
Development of efficient optimization algorithms to improve forecast models based on various influencing factors.
Maintenance and further development of the data preparation process of POS system data.

title: Word2Vec Playground
text:
I have crawled Netdoktor for my thesis at HSLU. The task at hand was to use Netdoktor as an additional source to the main data source to the one provided by IML. Unfortunatelly, I cannot share this confidential information, because the IML data consists of Multiple Choice Questions for medical students - and yes, I am talking about exam questions :P
However, I am therefore forced to create a Word2Vec model using public available data. Therefore, a data set is obtained by web crawling of Netdoktor1. Netdoktor is a free internet platform for medical information: It provides information about diseases and symptoms in German and other languages. The website is a part of the German media company Hubert Burda Media2 and was founded by Dr.¬†Carl Brandt and Rune Bech.
Let‚Äôs start to code :)

title: Word2Vec Playground
text:
Import Libraries and Data


Show the code
%matplotlib inline
import pandas as pd
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
sns.set_style("whitegrid")
sns.set(rc={'figure.figsize':(16, 8)})
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (16, 8)


from IPython.display import display, Markdown

df = (
    pd.read_pickle(
        '../data/corpus.pkl', 
        compression = {'method': 'gzip'},
    )
    # Select only columns 'disease', 'description', 'symptoms'
    [['disease','description','symptoms']]
)


df.head()






  
    
      
      disease

      Bei einer Alkoholvergiftung (Alkoholintoxikati...

      Die Plazenta (Mutterkuchen) ist ein Gewebe an ...
      Wie erkennt man eine vorzeitige Plazentaabl√∂su...

The data consists of 639 diseases and 3 columns.

title: Word2Vec Playground
text:
Exploration
First we perform some basic text exploration that includes: for each column we calculate the text length and we calculate of the number of tokens. We use the .str.split() methods from Pandas without any fancy library in the first step.


Show the code
df = (
    df
    .assign(
        len_description = lambda df: df.description.apply(len),
        len_symptoms = lambda df: df.symptoms.apply(len),
        tokens_description = lambda df: df.description.str.split(),
        tokens_symptoms = lambda df: df.symptoms.str.split(),
        n_tokens_description = lambda df: df.tokens_description.apply(len),
        n_tokens_symptom = lambda df: df.tokens_symptoms.apply(len),
    )
)

df_melted = (
    df
    .melt(
        id_vars='disease', 
        value_vars = ['len_description','len_symptoms','n_tokens_description','n_tokens_symptom']
    )
)




Show the code
plt.figure();
g = sns.displot(
    data = (
        df_melted.query('variable != "n_tokens_description" & variable != "n_tokens_symptom"')
    ),
    x = 'value',
    hue = 'variable',
    multiple = "stack",
);
plt.show(g)


<Figure size 1536x768 with 0 Axes>





On the left (figure above) shows the distribution of the length of description and on the right shows the distribution of the length of symptoms.


Show the code
plt.figure()
g = sns.displot(
    data = df_melted.query('variable == "len_description" | variable == "len_symptoms"'),
    x = 'value',
    hue = 'variable',
    multiple = "stack",
)
plt.show(g)


<Figure size 1536x768 with 0 Axes>

title: Predictive Maintenance - Part 1
text:
Objective
The objective of predictive maintenance is quite easy to explain: It is to predict when a machine or a component will fail or not. This makes it possible to move from a preventive maintenance approach to a predictive maintenance approach. This approach is more efficient because it allows to avoid unnecessary maintenance operations and to anticipate the failures of the machines. This approach is also more economical because it allows to avoid the immobilization of the machines for maintenance operations that are not necessary. The hard part of predictive maintenance is to get label, fail = yes and fail = no as well as the when. It sounds quite obvious, but, normally the maintenance schedule is organized in such a way, that the failure does not occur between the checks. In my current work, we have a lot of data, but we do not have the labels. So, we have to find a way to get the labels. In this post, I will show you how I did it.
Imagine you have a heating-ventilation-and-air-conditioning (HVAC) system. Normally, this system consists of several interconnected subsystems such as ventilation, heat-exchanger unit etc. Each of these subsystems consists of several components such as fans, pumps, valves, heat exchangers etc. Each of these components has a specific function and is subject to wear and tear. The wear and tear of these components can lead to a failure of the component. The failure of a component can lead to the failure of the subsystem. The failure of a subsystem can lead to the failure of the HVAC system. The failure of the HVAC leads to discomfort of the passengers. However, is it possible to predict the when based on historical data?
The important question is how to do it. In data science jargon, which variables lead to this state? What can be measured? One could measure the temperature of the air, the temperature of the water, the pressure of the air, the pressure of the water, the flow of the air, the flow of the water, the speed of the fans, the speed of the pumps, the position of the valves, the position of the dampers, the power consumption of the fans, the power consumption of the pumps, the power consumption of the heat exchangers, the power consumption of the HVAC system‚Ä¶ The most obvious technique is to concentrate on the power consumption and treat the subsystems etc. as detail information. This is what we did.


Coding
We used Gaussian-Mixture-Models1 to try to find a pattern which deviates from the normal behavior. The normal behavior corresponds to the historical data obtained by energy counters and lies with the distribution.


Show the code
import pandas as pd
import sklearn.mixture as mix
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
from sklearn.datasets import make_blobs

# Generate data
X, y = make_blobs(
    n_samples=100*60*24*7, 
    centers=3, 
    n_features=2,
    random_state=0
)







Footnotes


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixture_model‚Ü©Ô∏é
